App description:
Features:
-Explore the elevator shaft and four massive train levels full of mysteries, riches and strange happenings. Some fishy higher power seems to engulf the Frontier!

-Build up the way to the mines by gearing up and upgrading your vehicle. But beware, the adventure can end in eight different ways depending on the actions and choices taken.

-Meet a companion to help to carry the weight on your shoulders.

-Go on a treasure hunt for hidden magical loot.

-Item upgrades  technology advances in unimaginable ways, making mining more profitable!

-28 achievements and more to come in free content updates.

How much riches will be enough? Will you be able to stop? What happens if you dont? The answers to these questions and more will be found as you dig deeper into the mines!

zsoccer_05Jul 6 at 12:20 PM
Cave Digger

Hi! I have had this game for close to a week now and I have been playing a decent amount during these times. This game has some pros and many cons.

PROS

- The one thing I absolutely LOVE about this game is the ability to upgrade your town. This adds so much to work up to in the game.

- I also love the ability to drive/operate a train and go other places to mine.

- The mining details and animations are on point.

- I like that this game has a semi wide variety of items. Not much and not little, but is fine.

- I also love the radio because it gives you some sort of purpose for why you need to mine .

CONS

- The cave details are not good. While the overall detail is a tiny bit below par for the city and elevator, the caves details are gross. All the walls not including the mineable rocks are just blobs of grey color.

- Why is there a time limit on your mining? Although it is manageable mining with the infinity gauntlet, you have to swing your fist in the air so much. However when mining with the pickaxe you feel so rushed to be finished and throw everything in that little bucket thing in the center of the elevator.

- Glitches. There is one glitch that I cant across MANY times which makes it basically impossible to proceed. When mining after finding four of the five diamond things to put on your fist. you come across a fifth. When the fifth is finally on your hand everything darkens out and you are supposed to smash the earth with that fist. This was all very random because when it is open it looks like the inside of a watermelon! Shortly after the screen darkens again then you go to some sort of end scene where there is an old radio saying a bunch of stuff like this is the end of the game and more. You stay there for around five minutes doing nothing then you finally get teleported back. I had to go through this countless times because when I was mining it keeps coming up.

-There needs to be a bigger variety of pickaxes. The swinging pickaxe that you buy is actually not better than the one you start with.

- The inventory system needs to change. Although I like the hooks to put stuff on, five slots is just not enough for the amount of things you can buy. Also with the inventory being five little circles on your waist, it takes at least 20 seconds to put something there. Once they are and you try to pick something up from the floor by bending down, you will grab one of the items in your inventory instead. This is pretty frustrating given that you are on a short time limit and your are panicking trying to get all the gold and whatever you mine into the bucket thing. Now talking about the hooks, they are pretty useful but sometimes a pain to hang stuff on.

- Movement. I like that you can teleport around and walk around. But, the walking is just too fast. you touch the joystick slightly and you are at the other side of the elevator. It needs to be slower thats all.

Thank you for reading this far into my review and I hope to see at least some of these suggestions put into place! This game has a LOT of potential and I am really excited to see what will be done with it as time goes on.


Side note, I will be updating this list soon once I am able to explore the other half of the game, like using the train to go to different locations.

Addicting Fun, Unpolished, Potential

UPDATE: I am adding a star to my initial review due to the developers response. I like that he or she took the time to respond and are actively checking their reviews for feedback. Additionally, I havent come across these other worlds yet, which is intriguing. I am no longer on the fence. I am keeping the game and look forward to exploring it further.


Original review:
I decided To get this game based on the many stellar reviews.

After my son and I took turns playing for about an 1.5 hours, I am still on the fence on whether or not to keep it or return it.

The gameplay is addicting and there are little unique touches that are just really fun. Without giving anything away, I love the different endings and that you can keep going and not lose anything after the endings if you want to (at least for the two I experienced). The reason I am on the fence is 1. The graphics. When you are not in the elevator, they are just really bad on the quest. Its dark, dreary and hazy. When I ventured to the edge of the buildings in town, the lighting actually got brighter and it was a short lived delight. When you are used to playing so many games with crisp graphics on the Quest, the scenery makes you feel like you are playing a first draft of am amazing future release. I struggled to enjoy this game at times due to eye strain and the blurry setting during the train ride made me nauseous. Which brings me to the 2nd reason I am on the fence. Motion sickness. Although there is the ability to teleport, its not always consisted and when you are in the elevator, you instinctively end up using smooth movement because of the time limit.

Overall, this game will hopefully be amazing one day. Like I said, it is super fun and incredibly addicting, even with its faults. The train is a fabulous touch, the decision to allow for the gameplay to keep going even after you reach one of the endings was a wonderful decision and the many tools and upgrades you can buy with your mined profits, keeps the player engaged. Its the unpolished scenery and movement controls which bring this game down. Its a shame since the talented developers really have something special here.

Ps. For those of you concerned over the games Teen rating for drug use. Nothing to be concerned about in my opinion. I am guessing this is related to the mushrooms. If you eat them, one of those little unique touches that are just really fun comes into play. My young son just took it as a funny Easter egg type thing and it is. So far the game is quite wholesome and once polished up for the Quest, I could see this as being a must have for the kids.

I really enjoyed it but I have a few complaints:

First, general complaints.
1. The pause menu. Why is there an achievement menu but no pause menu? Why cant I see what the achievements are?
2. The point on the screen where the quality drops off is extremely noticeable in well lit areas. I understand that its there because of limits of the quest but can there be a more gentle transition?
3. The gauntlet. The whole charging up thing is annoying. Why does it light up even when I just grab something? Why cant I change which hand its on? (Pause menu would help with that) I still have no idea how the flying hand projectile is activated.
4. The shop. I would like to know what Im buying before buying it. Otherwise, its fine.
5. The belt thing. I always grab thing from it when I just want to pick up a loose gem. Maybe move it up a bit? The slots are too close together I think.
6. The general store. Why would I want to buy those things? I bought the well upgrade and so far its been $5000 wasted. I understand some like the train lever and Im guessing the gas mask is important later on but why can I make the well well-er?
7. The length. I got to the first ending about an hour and a half in which is my main reason for comparing this to a demo.

I had few problems with the elevator section. One was the glow from the special gems that go on your hand. It blocks your view of the surroundings and is overall obnoxious and should be toned down.

Now, the train. Here, most of my complaints are from the chest companion, but there are others too. First, why is it structured like a horror game? Long pathway with big open areas that you cant see the end of and branching, twisting paths. I found the holy hand grenade and had a mild panic attack when I saw the gravestone ignore that in quotes, I didnt know it was just random treasure loot. But still, why is there a gravestone? A nd now its time for the moment youve been waiting for: the mimic. I have no idea how it works. It sells things, I get that. But can I tell it where to go? What does it mean when it turns red? Even when it acknowledged the oils existence it just stands NEXT to it while none gets collected and just has its mouth wide open.

Overall, seems like the midpoint between a demo and full game currently. I did have a lot of fun and this should be taken constructively and not negatively. I hope there will continue to be updates.

Megabyte_gamerOct 30 at 10:21 PM
An honest review of my experience

So for starters, this review will contain spoilers for some of the endings in the game so be warned.

Cave digger is a good game to play. From the engaging mining experience that tests your swinging abilities to the many endings the game has to offer, this is a fun game to either play either by yourself to grind money or with your friends to see who can get the highest score. so far when it comes to endings, I've blown myself up with a nuke, blown the overworld up with a nuke just to return to an atomic wasteland, sent the elevator into space with a nuke, turned into the equivalent of thanos by collecting 5 infinity stones and destroying the earth, and put on a set of VR glasses and went to a retro version of the game. So what I'm trying to say is that it's a great game to play on any occasion.

Now if you're wondering why I made this a 3 star review instead of a 5 star review, it's because of the huge bug that I discovered that caused me a lot of trouble. So when I got back into the game after the first nuke ending, there are supposed to be upgraded versions of the tools that you can buy after you bought the originals but they were nowhere to be found. The only thing that was left for purchase was a key that you would buy to help unlock a secret vault in the shafts. I remembered seeing the upgraded tools in the shop before I set off that nuke but now they just dissapeared. So I played some more and unlocked a few of the endings before the thought hit me that maybe if I reset the game, then the lost items would return. So after resetting the game, sure enough, when I waited to get the tools, the upgraded ones finally appeared. Now recently I left VR to do something and when I tried to reenter cave digger, the game wouldn't load. So now I've been forced to uninstall the game and then reinstall it to see if it's still broken. So if VR kiwi could patch these bugs out of the game, I would rate 5 stars in a heartbeat.

Overall, this is a great game with a few major flaws that can easily be fixed. I would definitely recommend this game to you if you have the money to pay for it and the perseverance to get through any possible glitches.

Fun little game, but not the deepest

There are tools for mining, extracting artifacts, drilling for oil, and you can light and throw dynamite. For a mining game they really did cover all the bases. Its honestly way more than I expected from the title. Plus there are various items you can buy with all your loot. But at the end of the day, mining can only be so fun.

Best part of this game is the elevator shaft is small enough that I can typically play with no artificial locomotion. That lets you get immersed in the game and I love that.

The train takes you to caves where I am forced to venture out via joystick. That part is fun too because you can just explore and take your time. More relaxing than the elevator. My only complaint on the train is it takes way too long to get out and get back.

In general I would recommend the game. It keeps me entertained in the same way realvr fishing does even though it is simple. Just a relaxing time, and a lot of the relics you find are goofy, plus there is a silly ending involving an "infinity glove." However, I feel it fits in more with the $15 titles than $20, so I give it 3/5.
